{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3333420,"name":"Dan Langdon","username":"woodworker2001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/bbe5ce/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-14T23:43:46.931Z","cooked":"

We are experiencing an issue I cannot put my finger on. We have a sensor to mechanism set on a Kraken running phoenix 6. The StoM is 270 and some change. When we give use setPosition(value). The position the we give the motor and the its actual position are not exactly the same. They are very close like .001-.002 off, but when you go through a sensor to mech of 270 it is off by almost .1 degrees. I cant figure out why the position isnt exactly the number we are setting it to.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-14T23:43:46.931Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":66,"reads":180,"readers_count":179,"score":366.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":458711,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position","display_username":"Dan Langdon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51496,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position/458711/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3333568,"name":"amber","username":"amb","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/e36b37/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-15T03:28:02.291Z","cooked":"

0.1 degrees sounds negligible to me, it’s what I would expect from encoder count drift

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-15T05:13:59.885Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":167,"readers_count":166,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":458711,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position","display_username":"amber","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54285,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"not depressed programmer"},"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position/458711/2","custom_user_title":"not depressed programmer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3333649,"name":"Dan Langdon","username":"woodworker2001","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/w/bbe5ce/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-03-15T11:12:08.297Z","cooked":"

I would tend to agree but this isn’t drift. This is a number I am assigning to it and it is immediately off and through a 270:1 gearbox .1 degrees is quite a few ticks of the motor.

I know I must be doing something wrong but can’t figure it out. The motor should take the exact position assigned to it correct?

woodworker2001:

The motor should take the exact position assigned to it correct?

We’ve encountered the same thing. Haven’t found a way to fix it but it is pushing us towards using FusedCANCoders for similar setups in the future.

I’m not 100% sure but I think Kraken encoder position is absolute within 1 rotation. Maybe it’s rounding to that? Just a shot in the dark here

What is floating point error?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2024-03-17T15:04:07.391Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":39,"readers_count":38,"score":12.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":458711,"topic_slug":"phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position","display_username":"Dan Langdon","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":50682,"username":"hheroux24","name":"Hayden Heroux","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hheroux24/{size}/194558_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51496,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/phoenix-6-kraken-not-taking-exact-position/458711/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3335172,"name":"Hayden Heroux","username":"hheroux24","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/hheroux24/{size}/194558_2.png","created_at":"2024-03-17T16:04:47.862Z","cooked":"

Floating point numbers (floats, doubles, etc.) are a standard way of encoding base-10 numbers in a base-2 (binary) format. The conversion between them is not perfect; certain parts of the base-10 number line are densely packed with possible floating point numbers and certain others are not. When converting, it rounds to the nearest floating point number, which may be “far” away from the expected value; it is possible that the position that you are trying to set is “far” from a possible floating point number.
